en: You saw Doctor Goodstory yesterday and again this morning.
zh: 昨天你見到古德斯特里醫生，今天早上又見到他。

en: Aside from being tired a lot more often, you told him you don’t really feel a lot different.
zh: 你告訴他，除了經常感到疲憊之外並沒有什麼不適。

en: When you got home, you printed out the Ray Bradbury quote you like so much, and put it into a frame where you can see it from your desk.
zh: 你回到家，把你摯愛的雷·布拉德伯里的格言列印了出來，並把它鑲到鏡框里，這樣你可以在辦公桌旁看到它。

en: Sandra and Eva are still running around like the sky is falling.
zh: 桑德拉和伊娃依舊在四處奔波，就像天要塌下來似的。

en: It’s a really pretty stone church with lots of beautiful gardens out the front and a cemetery out the back, a horseshoe ring of poplars and oak trees separating the two.
zh: 這是一個用石頭砌成的教堂，前面是鬱鬱蔥蔥的花園，後面是墓地，中間隔著一片馬蹄形狀的樹林，種著楊樹、橡樹。

en: Of course that’s the old horror writer in you thinking that.
zh: 當然，這隻是你這個老恐怖小說家心裏的念頭。

en: You’ve probably forgotten this by now, Jerry, but your first few manuscripts were about vampires, and zombies, and shape-shifters.
zh: 你可能已經忘記了，傑瑞，你最初的幾部作品寫的是吸血鬼、殭屍和變形人。

en: Back then if you knew the real horror was waking up at three in the morning confused while taking a piss against the bedroom wall, that the real horror was stepping out your back door and stepping through a memory wormhole, then you’d have written a successful horror novel years ago.
zh: 要是那年你知道真正的恐怖就是凌晨三點迷迷糊糊地起來對著卧室的牆壁小便，或者走出後門穿過記憶蟲洞的話，你老早就會寫出暢銷的恐怖小說了。

en: Eva getting married at a church by a graveyard—the failed-to-be horror author can’t help but see the timing of all of this coinciding with the timing of the zombie uprising, the zombies choosing your little girl’s big day for a little big day of their own.
zh: 伊娃在墓地旁邊的教堂舉行婚禮，你這個恐怖小說作家真不忍心看到這一天也會成為殭屍的大日子，在女兒的婚禮當天來一場大暴動。

en: You feel bad Eva’s marrying her hip-hop-loving boyfriend in a place like this, but they’re doing it because of you, because Captain A Is taking you away, Yo.
zh: 你覺得伊娃在這種地方和她的嘻哈男友舉行婚禮有種不祥的預兆，但他們這樣做都是因為你啊，因為——

en: You were out on the deck with Hans when the florist came over to see Eva.
zh: 你和漢斯一起出去坐在露台上，這時花店老闆走了過來，她要見伊娃。

en: She smiled at you through the window of the French doors and you smiled back, and Hans grinned and slowly shook his head.
zh: 她透過法式門的窗戶沖你微微一笑，你也沖她一笑，漢斯笑著微微搖了搖頭。

en: No, you said, and shook your head.
zh: 「不是。」你搖著頭說。

en: I hear ya, mate. If things get to the point where you have to go into a care facility, and I’m sure they won’t, but if they do I’ll make sure there are some nurses in there who look like her.
zh: 「我聽說了，夥伴，等時機到了，你不得不住進療養院，我不敢肯定他們是否會送你進去，但我敢肯定會有和她相貌相仿的護士照顧你。」

en: Of course there’s no way he can do that, but the sentiment made you both laugh, and you can’t deny to yourself that if the nurses looked like the florist, then the nursing home can’t be all bad.
zh: 他不可能讓療養院里的護士和花店老闆長得相像的，但這一想法讓你們發笑，你不能否認自己有這樣的心思：如果有花店老闆模樣的護士，那麼住療養院也不算壞事。

en: You told Hans you’d started talking to yourself, and he said everybody does that sometimes, but he thought you meant you were saying things like Hmm, now where did I put the phone?
zh: 你告訴漢斯說，你開始自言自語了，他說有時候每個人都會這樣做的，他以為你的意思是說些「嗯，我把手機放在哪裡了？」

en: You told him about the conversations with Henry.
zh: 這樣的自言自語。你告訴他，你的自言自語是與亨利的對話。

en: Is he asking you to do things? Hans asked.
zh: 「他叫你做什麼事了嗎？」漢斯問。

en: Like what?
zh: 「比如呢？」

en: Like hurting people.
zh: 「比如傷害別人。」

en: You shook your head while you answered. No, it’s more normal than that. Like the conversation any old two friends would have.
zh: 你搖搖頭，回答說：「不是的，比這正常，就像兩個朋友間的對話。」

en: He the one who told you to spray-paint the neighbor’s house?
zh: 「是他讓你在鄰居家的房子上噴漆的？」

en: It was a good question, and one you couldn’t answer.
zh: 這個問題問得好，但你難以回答。

en: If you did spraypaint her house, was it on the suggestion of somebody who doesn’t exist?
zh: 如果你的確在她家的房子上噴漆了，是不是因為你聽從了某個不存在的人的建議？

en: At least you can’t leave the house without the alarms going off, right?
zh: 「至少你離開房屋時，不可能不觸發警報器，對不對？」

en: Hans pointed out. I can sneak out the windows.
zh: 漢斯說，「我可以偷偷翻窗出去。」

en: Just don’t let Henry talk you into sneaking out to visit your florist, huh?
zh: 「不要讓亨利誘導你溜出去看花店老闆，行嗎？」

en: He laughed then, and you laughed too, and why not?
zh: 他笑了，你也笑了，為什麼不能溜出去看她呢？

en: Everything is funny in Batshit County.
zh: 在瘋人縣發生的所有事都很可笑。

en: Good news—the weather report is good for the weekend. It’s plain sailing ahead.
zh: 好消息：天氣預報說，周末天氣晴好，萬事一帆風順。

en: Bad news—you’re going to Rick’s bachelor’s party later this week.
zh: 壞消息：這個星期晚些時候，你要參加瑞克的單身派對。

en: You don’t want to go, but Rick’s dad has promised to look after you. You’re only staying for the dinner part of the evening.
zh: 你不想去，但瑞克的爸爸已經答應照顧你了，你只是待在那兒吃頓晚飯。

en: Could be fun. Or it could be a nightmare.
zh: 大概會很有趣的，或者也可能是場噩夢。

en: Things will be better when this is all over.
zh: 當這些都結束時，一切都會好的。

en: Not just the wedding.
zh: 不只是婚禮。

en: It turns out Jerry does know what to do. Of course he does. It’s why he took Fiona Clark’s cell phone and searched her purse for cash.
zh: 以前的傑瑞知道該怎麼辦，他當然知道，這就是他拿走菲奧娜·克拉克的手機、翻她的錢包找現金的原因。

en: It’s like he was telling himself (or Henry was telling him) back in the house: he has to think of this like one of his books.
zh: 就像他在家裡自言自語（或者是亨利告訴他的）一樣，他得把現在的場景視作在他的書里發生的一樣。

en: What would the Bag Man do if he were innocent?
zh: 如果「黑袋狂魔」是無辜的，他會怎麼做呢？

en: The streets are different but look the same— same houses, same cars, same atmosphere, but then he finds a street that gets a little busier, and he follows it, like following narrow streams to bigger ones until you find the sea, and that’s what happens here, a sea of traffic, of people, a main road he can identify.
zh: ：相似的房子，同樣的汽車，熟悉的氛圍。後來他看到另一條有些繁忙的街道，他沿著街道繼續向前走，就像是最初看到小小的溪流，然後溪流匯聚成大江大河，再交錯成浩瀚的大海，車水馬龍一起湧向一條他可以確定的大道。

en: The good thing about Christchurch is you can’t drive for ten minutes in a straight line without passing within a mile of a mall, and he figures he’s about a thirty-minute walk from the nearest one now.
zh: 克萊斯特徹奇的一大優勢在於，你驅車直線行駛十分鐘就會穿過綿延一英里的商場。他心裏盤算著，距最近的那家商場還有三十分鐘的路程。

en: He must be used to walking, because the nursing home is a good distance out of town.
zh: 他一定是適應了步行，因為療養院距離市中心遙遠。

en: He wonders how long it took him to walk from there.
zh: 他不知道從那裡走進城需要用多長時間。

en: A long time. Maybe all night.
zh: 應該很長，也許要一整夜。

en: It takes him forty minutes to reach the mall.
zh: 他走了四十分鐘到達商場。

en: He hates malls. Yet he’s always thought that if you took the malls away, society would fall apart.
zh: 他討厭商場，然而，他又認為如果取消了商場，社會就會土崩瓦解。

en: He dismisses the idea of dumping the knife in one of the bins there. Whoever empties them could find it.
zh: 他打消了把刀子扔到垃圾箱里的想法，因為環衛工人清空垃圾箱時就能立即發現它。

en: He walks past an electronics store with half a dozen TVs pointing at him, some displaying TV shows he doesn’t recognize, and some displaying him as he walks past them, a camera sending back a live feed.
zh: 他經過一家電子商店，裏面有五六台電視機面向他，有的屏幕上播放著他沒看過的節目，有的在他走過時顯示著他的身影，原來這是攝像頭髮回的即時影像。

en: He walks past bookstores, shoe stores, a bank, a confectionary shop, jewelry stores, a sports store, stationary stores, a toy store with a giant stuffed pig in a tuxedo on display in the window.
zh: 他走過書店、鞋店、銀行、糖果店、珠寶店、體育用品店、文具店、玩具店，玩具店的櫥窗展示著一頭穿著燕尾服的巨大毛絨豬。

en: He reaches a supermarket with aisles full of sugary foods and bored-looking people.
zh: 他又走到一家超市，那裡有好幾條通道，擺滿了琳琅滿目的含糖食物，到處是無所事事的人。

en: He buys a bottle of water and a sandwich and a SIM card.
zh: 他買了一瓶水、一個三明治、一張電話卡。

en: The girl at the checkout asks if he’s having a good day, and rather than telling her the truth he tells her it’s going well, then asks how her day is going.
zh: 結賬時，那個女收銀員問他今天是否過得愉快，他沒有告訴她事情的真相，只是對她說一切還好，又問她今天過得怎麼樣。

en: She tells him it’s also going fine, and he guesses it is for her because he didn’t wake up in her house earlier.
zh: 她告訴他挺好，他心想她是挺好的，因為他之前並沒有在她家的房子里醒來。

en: When he heads back to the mall exit he passes the shops in the reverse order, the only difference is the TVs on display are now showing the news, and on the news is a picture of him, Jerry Grey. . . .
zh: 他走向商場出口，又逐一經過剛剛走過的商店，與來時唯一不同的是，現在電視里都播放著新聞，新聞里出現了他的照片，傑瑞·格雷……

en: You are Jerry Grey.
zh: 你是傑瑞·格雷。

en: “The author who wrote under the pseudonym Henry Cutter . . .”
zh: 「那個用筆名亨利·卡特寫作的作者……」

en: You are Henry Cutter.
zh: 你是亨利·卡特。

en: “. . . has disappeared from the nursing home . . .”
zh: 「……從療養院里溜出來了……」

en: You live in a nursing home.
zh: 你住在療養院。

en: “. . . he was committed to after the murder of Sandra Grey, his wife . . .” You murdered your wife.
zh: 「他殺死了桑德拉·格雷——他的妻子——之後……」

en: He heads to the sporting store he passed a minute earlier. He spends half of his remaining cash on an overpriced rugby cap (go All Blacks!) and tugs it tightly over his head and tucks the front of it down a little.
zh: 他向一分鐘之前經過的那家體育商店走去，用剩餘現金的一半買了頂標價很高的橄欖球帽（全黑色），牢牢地套在頭頂，並把帽檐使勁向下拉。

en: From there he heads to the bathrooms and finds an empty stall and locks the door and sits inside.
zh: 他向洗手間走去，發現一個空位，便鎖上門坐在裏面。

en: On the back of the door somebody has written at the top Damien is awesome, and below that people have written other things, reminding Jerry of the comment sections online, a long list starting with That’s because Damien has a vagina and ending with Fuck the world.
zh: 門的背面有人在上面寫道：「達米安真棒。」底下有人跟著寫了長長一列文字，這讓傑瑞想到網上的評論。底下第一行寫著：「因為達米安有陰|道。」結尾寫著：「操蛋的世界。」

en: He opens the packet with the SIM card and slots the card into Fiona Clark’s phone.
zh: 他打開卡包取出電話卡，插|進菲奧娜·克拉克的手機。

en: He starts to call Hans and straightaway there’s a problem. He has no idea what Hans’s number is.
zh: 他開始給漢斯打電話了，但馬上就浮現出一個問題：他不記得漢斯的號碼。

en: Why would he?
zh: 為什麼會這樣呢？

en: He hasn’t remembered anybody’s number in a while now, and not because of the dementia, but because his smartphone has remembered everything for him for several years now. He’s lost the habit of committing numbers to memory, and maybe that’s where all of this started.
zh: 他記不住任何人的電話號碼，並非因為老年痴呆症，而是因為多年以來他的智能手機為他記住了一切，他已經習慣不去記電話號碼了，也許這就是這一切的開端也說不定。

en: Is this what he’s done the other times he’s escaped the nursing home?
zh: 他在其他時間逃出療養院時，情況也是這樣的嗎？

en: In this day and age there has to be a way, doesn’t there?
zh: 在如今這個時代，一定會有解決的辦法，對不對？

en: A goddamn way of calling somebody! How difficult can it be?
zh: 該死的，給人打電話能有多難？

en: He bangs the palm of his hand into the side of his head. Come on! Those numbers are in there somewhere!
zh: 他拍了一下頭，那些號碼一定在什麼地方！

en: Calm down, Jerry.
zh: 「冷靜下來，傑瑞。」

en: The voice of reason. The voice of Henry Cutter, who wrote the most unreasonable things until a ghost had to start writing them for him.
zh: 這理智的聲音是亨利·卡特的，他寫了一連串不合常理的故事，直到代筆開始替他寫。

en: The numbers may not be in there, but what about emails? He’s right.
zh: 「電話號碼可能不記得，但電子郵件呢？」他是對的。

en: Jerry hasn’t used email in a long time, but if he can access his account then he can email Hans.
zh: 傑瑞已經有很長時間沒有寫過電子郵件了，但如果他能夠登錄賬戶，那麼他還是可以給漢斯發送電子郵件的。

en: He uses the phone to go online, and he has to concentrate, really concentrate to remember his own email address so he can log in, letting his fingers roam over the phone, being guided by muscle memory, which he manages to do, the address coming to him, and back in the day—the day of Sane Jerry—he used the same password for everything.
zh: 他必須集中精力，集中精力，好想起自己的電子郵箱地址，這樣就可以登錄。他的手指在手機上划來划去，想通過肌肉的記憶回憶起電子郵箱地址。回想當年，在傑瑞神志正常的那些日子里，他所有的賬戶都設置成一樣的密碼。

en: In the password field he types Frankenstein. Five seconds later he has access to his account.
zh: 他在密碼區輸入Frankenstein幾個字母，五秒鐘后，他成功地訪問了自己的賬戶。

en: There are over eleven hundred unread emails. He doesn’t read any, and is about to compose one of his own to Hans when he remembers that not only does he have access to his emails, but also to an online address book.
zh: 郵箱里有超過一千一百封的未讀郵件，但他一封也沒有讀，他準備給漢斯發郵件，忽然想起他既然登錄了郵箱，那就能訪問在線地址簿。

en: Hans’s number is there.
zh: 那兒說不定有漢斯的電話號碼。

en: The whole bathroom smells like wet dog and bleach.
zh: 整個洗手間充斥著狗臊味和漂白劑的味道。

en: Hans doesn’t answer. He leaves a message.
zh: 漢斯沒有應答，他便發了條短消息。

en: He thinks about what other options he has.
zh: 他在想他還有什麼其他可以做的。

en: He looks back through his contacts and Eva’s number is in there.
zh: 他又重新看了看通信錄，上面還有伊娃的號碼。

en: Could he call her?
zh: 他可以打電話給她嗎？

en: He decides to give it a few minutes in case Hans calls back, which is exactly what happens.
zh: 他決定再等幾分鐘，等漢斯回撥過來。他真的回電了，他接起電話。

en: “It’s me,” Hans says.
zh: 「是我。」漢斯說，「對不起，我沒有接電話。

en: “I’m in trouble,” Jerry says, the words falling out of him, the sense of relief almost overwhelming.
zh: 「我有麻煩了。」傑瑞說。

en: “I know,” Hans says.
zh: 「我知道。」漢斯說。

en: “No,” Jerry says, “you have no idea.”
zh: 「不，」傑瑞說，「你不知道。」

en: “Eva called me earlier, plus now it’s on the news and—”
zh: 「伊娃之前給我打過電話，再加上現在的新聞，還有……」

en: “It’s worse than that,” Jerry says.
zh: 「比那還要糟糕。」傑瑞說，「你能來幫幫我嗎？

en: “Can you come and get me? Please? I really need help.
zh: 求求你了，我真的需要幫助。

en: I’m at a mall.”
zh: 我在一家商場。」

en: “Which one?”
zh: 「哪一家？」

en: “It’s . . .” he says, and he knows the name of the mall, it’s on the tip of his tongue. “I can’t think straight.”
zh: 「是……」他說，他知道商場的名字，它就在嘴邊了，卻說不出來，「我想不起來了。」

en: “Go and find a security guard, or the mall management office and tell them who you are. You can wait there while—”
zh: 「去找保安，或者去商場諮詢台，告訴他們你是誰，你可以在那裡等著我

en: “I can’t do that,” Jerry says, shaking his head.
zh: 「我不能。」傑瑞搖著頭說。

en: A pause for a few seconds from Hans’s end of the phone, and then, “What is it you’re not telling me?”
zh: 漢斯在電話的另一端停頓了幾秒，爾後他說：「你還有什麼沒有告訴我？」

en: Jerry stares down at the bag with the sandwich and the bottle of water he bought earlier.
zh: 傑瑞低頭看看那個塑料袋，那裡面裝著他剛買的三明治和水。

en: “I’ll tell you when you get here.
zh: 「等你到了這裏我再告訴你。

en: I’ll go out front and see what mall it is and I’ll call you back.”
zh: 我到外面去看看這是哪家商場，然後給你回電話。」

en: “What’s happened, Jerry?”
zh: 「發生了什麼事，傑瑞？」

en: “I’ll tell you when you get here. I’ll call you back.”
zh: 「等你到了這裏我再告訴你，我會給你回電話的。」

en: “Just stay on the line, Jerry.”
zh: 「不要掛電話，傑瑞。」

en: He walks out of the bathroom and into the river of people carrying books and DVDs and clothes, some pushing strollers, some pushing shopping carts, and he walks to the same entrance he came through earlier.
zh: 他走出洗手間，融進人群當中。他們有的捧著書，有的拿著DVD，有的拿著衣服，有的推著嬰兒車，有的推著購物車。他走到之前進來的那個入口，到了外面，他轉過身，看到幾個大寫字母，想必那就是商場的名字了。

en: He tells Hans, and Hans tells him to stay exactly where he is, and that he’ll be there in ten minutes.
zh: 他告訴了漢斯，漢斯讓他待在原地，他將在十分鐘後到這裏。

en: Jerry hangs up and tucks the phone into his pocket.
zh: 傑瑞掛斷電話，把手機塞進口袋。

en: He opens up the bottle of water and drinks a quarter of it while staring out at the cars, all while staying exactly where he said he would stay.
zh: 他打開那瓶水，喝掉了四分之一。他盯著那些車，它們都井然有序地停靠在他說他會待在的地方。

en: He’s opening the sandwich packet when it hits him.
zh: 他打開那包三明治時，突然就想到了什麼。

en: He’s left the bag with the towel and the knife back in the bathroom.
zh: 他把裝著毛巾和刀的塑料袋落在了洗手間里！

en: He is desperate to start running, but restrains himself as to not draw attention.
zh: 他不顧一切地狂奔，又努力克制著自己，以免引起注意。

en: There are so many shops, so many ways to turn, so many people around him as he walks. He can’t figure out how to get back to the bathroom, not right away, and by the time he does his ten minutes are up and Hans is ringing him.
zh: 這麼多商鋪、這麼多轉彎、這麼多人，他全然不知該怎樣回到洗手間了。

en: He opens the bathroom door and goes to the stall where he sat earlier.
zh: 他打開洗手間的門，跑向他之前待過的隔間。

en: It’s empty.
zh: 是空的。

en: He looks at the back of the door to make sure it’s the same stall. Fuck the world.
zh: 他看著門的背面，確定了這是相同的隔間——「這操蛋的世界！」

en: The bag with the towel and the knife has gone.
zh: 裝著毛巾和刀的塑料袋不翼而飛了。
